Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Alexander R. Perry is "Derived Categories in Algebraic Geometry." The host institution for the fellowship is Columbia University, and the sponsoring scientist is Johan de Jong.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to study interactions between classical algebraic geometry and derived categories of coherent sheaves. Classical algebraic geometry aims to classify the geometric objects -- called algebraic varieties -- defined by systems of polynomial equations. The derived category of an algebraic variety is a modern tool that can be thought of as a sophisticated "linear approximation" to the variety.

The project resulted in 13 papers (9 published or accepted for publication, and 4 submitted for publication), largely around the following themes.

1) Structural results for derived categories: The PI's work includes a theory of homological projective geometry, which gives a powerful tool for relating derived categories of different varieties.

2) Bridgeland stability and moduli spaces: The PI's work includes a generalization of Bridgeland stability to the relative setting, which gives a powerful tool for constructing families of moduli spaces from derived categories.

3) Applications to classical algebraic geometry: The PI used derived category methods to resolve the birational Torelli problem for Calabi-Yau threefolds, construct the first infinite series of unirational locally complete families of polarized hyperkahler varieties, prove new cases of the integral Hodge conjecture, and shed light on the prominent rationality problem for cubic fourfolds.

The broader impacts of the project include wide dissemination of mathematics, as well as mentorship and education of young mathematicians. Over the course of the project, the PI delivered over 50 research talks at locations around the world. The PI co-organized a workshop at the American Institute of Mathematics, and co-organized Columbia's algebraic geometry seminar for two years. The PI also lectured at a learning workshop, and mentored a group of graduate students at an online workshop. Finally, the PI co-supervised an REU project, and supervised an undergraduate's independent study of algebraic geometry.
